Preface to the Brief Biographies of the Lineage Holders:
The good and virtuous spiritual friends in the side branches,
Have already been recorded in other books.
This is because they all come from the true lineage.
Although the direct and indirect descendants are different,
Their Dharma is the same.
The Zhou dynasty enfeoffed states with the same surname,
In order to honor their lineage.
The principle of close relatives,
Then Wen, Wu, Cheng, and Kang are the main ones.
Comparing it to the direct succession from MahÄkÄÅ›yapa,
One can understand it.
The transmission begins with Matai-teki,
And ends with Chan Master Shenhui of Yizhou.
There are a total of two hundred and fifty people.
The second ancestor, Venerable Ä€nanda,

The twenty-fourth patriarch, the Venerable Shizi.
His dharma heirs who branched out include one person.
Called the Venerable Damo.
The second generation after Shizi.
The Venerable Damo.
A person from the country of KaÅ›mÄ«ra.
Of an inauspicious surname.
First, he left home under the Venerable Pali of that country.
Quite intelligent and with wisdom and eloquence.
And his virtue surpassed that of all the arhats.
When the Dharma of Pali was divided into five schools.
And the Venerable One was the foremost in the Chan meditation school.
Later, he debated with the Venerable Shizi.
And was finally subdued by his Way.
He then took Shizi as his teacher.
When Shizi was killed.
Damo went into hiding with his two disciples in Xiangbai Mountain in that country.
His age and lifespan were very high, beyond the usual count.
His dharma heirs he produced were two people.
One was called Indra.
One was called Guolujili.
Commentary says:
At the beginning, the foolish one had not yet attained realization. At the time of recording the exit from the three repositories,
There were some who said, I have doubts.
The position of ancestor ends with the lion.
But its Dharma is transmitted everywhere.
Is it not so for the Sixth Ancestor, Chan Master Dajian?
Therefore, I once discussed this with him, saying,
The ending of the position of ancestor is indeed an extraordinary matter.
The sages of the past and present should also speak of it.
If the number of ancestors ends with Dajian,
Then there is Prajnatara and Bodhidharma the Great who make predictions about it.
Although the Sixth Ancestor each transmits his Dharma, there are also people.
If what you call the ancestral generation ends with the lion,
What evidence is there for it?
Who among the previous ancestors ever recorded it?
And what people actually transmitted the Dharma?
Are they going to the East?
If it is not people, how could their Dharma reach this far?
Although the side branch of Bodhidharma's Dharma is self-divided,
The people he produces are no more than four or five people each.
It is not a universal transmission.
I have never heard that his disciples spread the Dharma to the East.
If you take Bodhidharma as the universal transmitter,
then why did Bodhidharma point to the 25th ancestor and say:
I have a classmate named Parshva.
My former teacher entrusted the Dharma to him in advance.
He also gave him the robe as a token of faith.
He has already gone to South India.
Why would he ignore his other classmates and not mention them?
This is not so.
You should seek the truth through reasoning.
You should not indulge in your own speculations.
He said, If that is so, then since Bodhidharma was the disciple of Simha Bhiká¹£u,
how could he not accept him as his orthodox ancestor?
Why did he push it to Parshva?
He said, This is probably because the sages should be called ancestors according to their karmic conditions.
It is also because of the shallowness and depth of their enlightenment that they are given the Dharma seal.
If the 5th ancestor transmitted it to the Great Mirror,
but did not pass it on to Bi Xiu,
Is this not so?
Some agree with this.
I happened to obtain Seng You's writings.
And my words are very accurate.
I do not want to discard them.
So I attach them after the biography of Dharma-datta.

The Brief Transmission of the Patriarchs and Sages, with a Preface. The preface says:
The Nirvana Sutra says:
Again, in other places where there are poisonous arrows of afflictions,
He manifests as a patriarch to treat them.
It also says:
I have already entrusted my unsurpassed true Dharma to MahÄkÄÅ›yapa.
KÄÅ›yapa will be a great reliance for you all.
This is truly the patriarch of my Way.
But the transmission from India to China is not true.
It causes the virtue of the sages to not be very clear or effective.
Moreover, the tyrannical ruler is jealous of goodness and destroys the great teaching.
And the Buddha's disciples are not good at writing.
Falsely claiming that their patriarchs ended at the twenty-fourth generation.
This gives rise to doubts among those born in later generations.
The sage's virtue is even more diminished.
I have always lamented this.
Recently, while editing books,
I obtained the ten works on the affairs of the ancestral sages by various sages.
Therefore, I have compiled them together with their authors.
This is the Transmission of the Ancestral Evidence.ğŸ”½The Å›ramaá¹‡a Zhu Dali of the Yuezhi country
was a disciple of the twenty-third patriarch Hureluna.
He was naturally intelligent
and was able to understand both the Great and Lesser Vehicles of Buddhism.
He was called a tripiá¹­aka master in his country.
In the time of Emperor Xian of the Han dynasty, he arrived in Luoyang.
He once translated the Sutra of the Two Original Beginnings together with the Å›ramaá¹‡a Kang Mengxiang.
One day, a white light suddenly appeared in front of the place where he was staying.
Dali composed himself and said,
This light is the sign of the passing of my teacher Hureluna.
The assembly found this strange and reported it to the emperor.
The emperor then ordered it to be recorded.
At that time, it was the year of the zhou.
He then traveled to the south of the Yangtze River.
Just as Sun Quan proclaimed himself king in Jiankang and was beginning to revere the Buddha's teachings,
he established a temple and treated the Å›ramaá¹‡a Kang Senghui with respect in his country.
When Senghui first saw Dali,
he did not respect him very much.
He then used questions and answers,
and they came to respect each other.
He said,
What teacher do you have to be able to do this?
Dali said,
My teacher is Ká¹£ÄntivÄdi.
Therefore I have attained this wonderful understanding.
He then penetrated the minds of others.
Senghui said,
How many people like you and your teacher are there who have sharp wisdom?
Are there any who surpass you?
Dali said,
There are three thousand people like me.
As for those who are outstanding and extraordinary, there is only one person.
He is called the bhiká¹£u Siá¹ƒha.
He secretly received the true Dharma and will succeed my teacher.
He is now spreading the teachings in the country of Northern India.
Senghui then introduced him to the ruler of Wu,
praising his extraordinariness.
The ruler of Wu then asked Dali,
I am honored to have this land.
How long will the country's blessings last?
Dharmaraká¹£a then replied with a verse:
Eating in the clear night,
Fighting and running in the clouds,
At the end of the fourteenth year,
One will surely meet a pig's mouth.
At that time, Sun Quan did not understand the words,
But he also greatly honored him.
MahÄ-bala stayed in Wu for a long time.
When Sun Quan died, his son Liang succeeded to the throne.
He met with MahÄ-bala more and more often,
And everything he said had effective results.
MahÄ-bala then returned to the Western Regions in the Gengchen year of the Sun-xu era.
The Indian monk Dharmaraká¹£a,
In the third year of the Renyin era of the Wei Dynasty,
Arrived in Xuchang.
At first, he saw that the monks' deportment was not proper and sighed over it.
He said they did not know the Vinaya.
At that time, there was a monk named Guangcan in Xuchang,
Who was wise among the assembly and was able to treat him well.
He then bowed and asked Dharmaraká¹£a,
What are the most excellent teachers that you have seen in the Western Regions?
By what Dharma do they uphold the teachings?
Please instruct me on this.
Kara said:
In the Western Regions, there are generally two great and excellent monks.
One is Manjushri and the other is Haklena.
I have all paid homage to them.
These two great beings all transmit the true Dharma to uphold the teachings.
Those who are in their assembly are few and not well-disciplined.
However, both great beings have attained the holy path.
And their extraordinary virtues are all unfathomable.
As for Manjushri,
he first used his spiritual powers to beat his belly in the country of Nati.
He was then able to subdue a million vicious elephants.
When he left home,
he taught in western India.
In that country, he pointed out the location of a stupa and a spring.
All of them had verified effects, as recorded in his biography. Haklena was his successor's disciple.
He greatly promoted Buddhist activities in the country of Central India.
When he passed away, the four assemblies cremated him.
They were about to divide his relics.
Huileuna again manifested.
He spoke a verse to admonish them.
Not allowing them to divide the relics, the verse is also complete in his biography. Guangcan said:
Has he been in nirvana for a long time or recently?
Karuna said:
Twelve years.
Guangcan said:
Are the years and calendar in the Western countries roughly the same as here?
Karuna said:
Although the names differ,
the climate is no different.
He then spoke of the calendar of the five regions of India and so on.
KÄÅ›yapa then returned to the west.
Guangcan immediately transmitted the matter.
Later authors of the Biographies of Eminent Monks
were able to record it.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a Zhiqiang Lianglou of the country of MadhyadeÅ›a
was a person who truly attained the fruits of the path and was unfathomable.
He arrived in Luoyang during the time of Cao Huan, the Prince of Chenliu of the previous Wei dynasty.
He first stayed at Baima Temple.
It was the Xinsi year of the second year of the Gaizhi era.
At that time, the Wei Dynasty was in decline.
Huandeng and his colleagues were worried about it.
They heard that there was an extraordinary monk from the Western Regions.
They often asked him about the prosperity and decline of their country.
The monk from the Western Regions then spoke a verse to Huandeng, saying:
The two gentlemen rely on empty positions.
Monkeys are in the right path.
Five people hold a chicken.
The chicken crows, and the monkeys do nothing.
After Huandeng left, the monk from the Western Regions spoke another verse, saying:
The two gentlemen go well.
They will be safe for two years.
A woman will give birth in Henan.
Zhu Lun will advance to the altar.
At that time, although they did not understand the meaning,
later everything was verified.
Soon, Tanti, Kang Sengkai, and Tansongbai
invited various monks to translate various sutras.
One said:
